div.stage: As they are going out, they are met by a party of Scythians, bringing back the four Prieſteſſes, and the Image.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Scyth.
sp.p: Here, Here are their Accomplices, fall on:

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Hold Savages, O Hold.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: Forbear, Forbear.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: As for us two, we yield our ſelves your Captives,
Touch not with Impious Hands her Sacred Limbs.

sp.speaker: Scyth.
sp.l: I had forgot, ſhe is Dianas Prieſteſs,
Keep off your Hands, but guard her with your Eyes.
So;
Be it your Care the Priſoners to confine,
I'll to the Queen Relate their black Deſign.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Ah wretched Men! by cruel God's betray'd.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: Pity thy ſelf alas too lovely Maid.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Death ſoon will put an end to all our woe,
But Oh what pangs art thou to undergoe,
Who art condemn'd to ſtike th' Inhuman Blow.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: ACT IV.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: WHat have I heard! Arm'd Men upon the Breach!

sp.speaker: Scyth.
sp.l: Above an hundred, all with Grecian Plumes,
And Grecian Shields.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Double the Guards around the Temple,
And ſtrongly guard the Paſſes.
Who ſaw theſe Grecians?

sp.speaker: Scyth.
sp.l: As we expecting lay for your Return,
Upon the Summe • of yon ſhagg • e Mountain,
That bending its black Brow, with dreadful Scowl,
Over the gloomy Deep, affrights great Neptune,
By the pale Moon's reflected Beams we ſpied them:
And on the ſight, diſmounting all my Men,
I brought them to defend your ſacred Perſon.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: And ſo, upon your March at this dead Seaſon,
You took theſe Grecian Fugitives: 'Tis well;
You have done important Service, and I thank you.
But what's the Reaſon that the younger Captive
Is not already in my Preſence?
My ſevere Charge how dare they diſobey?

sp.speaker: Scyth.
sp.p: Behold, dread Queen, he comes.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Then go and ſee my other Orders executed.
Whom wou'd not that Majeſtick Mien deceive?
And his Friend's God-like Eyes that look Divinity?
Why ſhou'd the Sacred Character of Virtue
Shine on a Villain's Countenance? Ye Pow'rs!
Why fix'd ye not a Brand on Treaſon's Front,
That we might know t' avoid perfidious Mortals?
Look if the Traytor once vouchſafes to bluſh!
If ſtill his Countenance be not aſſur'd!
His Eyes Commanding, and his Aſpect Lordly!
How do'ſt thou dare, with that audacious Look,
T' affront offended Majeſty?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: I know no Mortal whom I ought to fear.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: An Hypocrite, and not afraid!
What makes Hypocriſie ſo very odious?
Unleſs becauſe 'tis Cowardice.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Know, Queen, I ſcorn Hypocriſie, and know
The baſeſt of Hypocriſies is Slander.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: And am I then defi'd, preſumptuous Grecian,
And dar'd to prove my Charge?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: I dare ev'n Jove, who knows all Hearts, to pro •••• t.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Then, paſt Reply thou ſoon ſhalt ſtand convicted.
When I in Mercy gave you Life and Liberty,
Did you not own your ſelf oblig'd?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: I own it.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: But when Diana's Prieſteſs I beſtow'd on you,
Did not you ſeem tranſported? Anſwer me.
Was not your Joy extravagant and loud?
Did you not ſwear, that I, of all the World,
Was ſhe who neareſt had oblig'd your Soul?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: I ſaid it, and I thought it.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Did you not promiſe to reſide in Scythia?
And to engage your Friend to do the like?
That with the Service of your Life you might
Return me, Thanks for the rich Preſent made you?
Were not theſe very Words your own?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: They were.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Then think of thy baſe Flight, if thou dar'ſt think of it,
And ſay, thou art not a Hypocrite.
What canſt thou anſwer to thy juſt Accuſer?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: That which will make my Accuſer ſay, ſhe wrongs me.
You accuſe me that I wou'd have fled: Indeed
I attempted to regain that Liberty,
Of which your Pow'r unjuſtly had depriv'd me.
What Reaſon cou'd you find, inſulting Queen,
To make them Captives whom the Gods made free,
And gave them Souls deſerving Liberty?
As againſt Nature's Laws we are your Victims,
Againſt the Right of Nations we're your Captives;
And any way was lawful to fair Liberty,
Which we were born for, and for which we'll die.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: That very Moment I reſtor'd your Liberty.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Indeed you did reſtore it, but on Terms
Impoſſible to be perform'd by us.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Why did you then approve them?

sp.speaker: Phel.
sp.p: I never knew them well till I had left you.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: A meer Pretence! Is Grecian Faith ſo known?
Had not you giv'n that Faith to remain here?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: But then that Faith was on Conditions giv'n;
Which ſoon I found you never cou'd perform.

sp.speaker: Queen,
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: Becauſe the Gift you offer'd, was no Gift.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: What was no Gift? The Preſent which you priz'd ſo!

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Had it been real, it had been ineſtimable.
You only gave me Words, and the vain Promiſe
Of what the Gods had taken from your Pow'r.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Surely thou raveſt,
Is not Diana's Prieſteſs in my Pow'r?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Her Body is; but tho' it be a glorious One
Without her Soul, I wou'd refuſe the Treaſure:
But love alone can of her Soul diſpoſe;
And, without leave obtain'd of you,
The God had frankly done it.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Ha! To whom!

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: How fain you wou'd extort this Secret from me?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: How fain I wou'd? by Heav'n I will extort it.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: You never ſhall; I know I am to bleed,
And with me too the fatal Truth ſhall die.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Then 'tis no Truth, and thou wilt die a Villain:
Die with the Brand of an ungrateful Traytor,
An odious Hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: To be reveng'd for theſe opprobrious Wrongs,
I need but tell you what you ask, proud Princeſs.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Do it then.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: Will you perſiſt to urge me?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: I will. The Prieſteſs! Who has touch'd her Heart?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: In your own Breaſt the fatal Secret's lodg'd.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Lodg'd in my Breaſt!

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Ask, ask your ſelf the Queſtion, who is he
Who finds the way of touching Scythian Hearts?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Ha! Gods! That ſtings.
Here Guards, withdraw your Pris'ner,
And bring Diana's Prieſteſs hither inſtantly.
By yon Bright Goddeſs, He's come off with Honour.
But Oh, the exalted Virtue of his Friend!
Who freely for his Friend can Life reſign,
And for his Miſtreſs can contemn a Crown!
This Raiſes him ſtill more in my Eſteem.
It wou'd do, had he made a better Choice.
And is the Prieſteſs then preferr'd to me?
Have I, who have had the Ambition to behold
Admiting Monarchs at my Feet adoring,
Li • 'd to reflect, with mortifying Soul,
That I my ſelf, to one unknown, have offer'd,
And been, O Gods! by one unknown refus'd?
And for Diana's Prieſteſs too refus'd!
Refus'd! Scorn'd! loath'd! Oh, how that tears my Heart!
But if thou haſt a Soul, with treble Scorn
Return it: Suffer him to take this Prieſteſs;
And let his deſpicable Choice revenge thee.
What! muſt he gain her by the odious Boaſt,
That he has ſacrific'd me to my Creature?
And can I ſuffer it? I cannot think of it
Without Diſtraction. But the Prieſteſs comes.
So; From whence come you? Ha! whence theſe Diſorders?
What makes you tremble? And what ſtrikes you dumb?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: To ſuch a haughty and inſulting Look
I have not learnt to anſwer.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: I look, as it becomes me, on my Slave.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: The ſight of ſuch a Slave ſhou'd make you humble,
By ſhewing you to what exceſs of Wretchedneſs
The Daughter of a mighty King may fall.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Say, From whence come you? I command you anſwer.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: I have no Pow'r to ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: So haſty was your Flight?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Who muſt not fly from acting Cruelties,
At which Barbarity it ſelf can melt?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Oh, how thoſe meek and melting Words
Become the ſoft and tender Race of Tantalus!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: The Race of Tantalus has been revengeful:
But yet it ne'er was bloody unprovok'd.
What have theſe Grecians done to me?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: What hadſt thou done t' aſſembled Greece at Aulis?
What hadſt thou done to thy own Father there?
Who to thy Ruin, unprovok'd, conſented;
Nay, preſs • d it, urg'd it.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: My Mother urg'd it not.
I from the Heroines of our Race have • e • rnt
To ſhew ſoft Pity.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Thou from the Heroines of thy Race haſt learnt,
Thou haſt, fond Maid, to ſhew a guiltier Paſſion.
Oh, how their kind Reception of their Gueſts
Had made their Names throughout the World renown'd!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: For an Example of ſuch kind Reception,
Perhaps I need not fly to Greece.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I underſtand thee well.
Plagu'd by the Terrors of impending Wrath,
Thou would'ſt provoke and haſten Death, thou would'ſt,
And have him ſwifter that he may be gentler,
But know, fond Maid, thou ſhalt not die ſo early,
Think of thy Gratitude to thy Preſerver,
And think what that deſerves.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: My preſerver!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Was ever ſuch audacious inſolence?
Who was it ſav'd thee from immediate Death,
At thy Arrival on the S •••• of Tauris?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Would I had been a Man at that Arrival,
For then my Blood had •• ain'd your cruel Altars!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: O wretch, ingrateful to that black Degree,
As to diſown the mighty Obligation,
By which thou liv'ſt to ſa •• thou art not oblig'd!
Would'ſt thou inſinuate that thy Sex preſerv'd thee?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Men are the Victims that your Goddeſs claims!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Not always.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Tradition ſays ſo, and your bloody Rites
Are founded on Tradition.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: When ſhe her ſelf declares her awful Will,
Tradition's of no force.
But not the feeble voice of faint Tradition;
No, the loud call of the deſcending Goddeſs,
Claim'd thee at Aulis her devoted Victim,
At leaſt ſo Calchas ſaid.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: The fraud of Calchas plainly ſhe Detected,
By ſuffering me to evade th'inhuman Altar.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: 'Twas Clytemneſtra's Sacrilege preſerv'd thee,
And not the Goddeſs;
Who wracking thee on this her ſacred Shore,
Strongly appears to Redemand her Fugitive.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Before theſe Grecians came you had no ſuch thoughts.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: No, thy ſoft graceful look, and ſeeming innocence,
Inclin'd me to ſuſpect the crafty Calchas.
But thy black Guilt appearing with thy Ingratitude,
Makes me repent of my miſtaken pity.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: O fatal pity▪ Rightly term▪d miſtaken?
True pity would have ſuffered me to bleed;
Then I had been at reſt in the Dark Grave,
With my unhappy Parents!
Not have convers'd with everlaſting woe,
In you Dire Tabernacle of Deſpair!
For there no ſmiling Beam of Joy is ſeen;
No gladſom ſound is ever heard,
But all is always rueful Lamentation,

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: If thuo'rt ſo ſenſible of this,
Then know that there's a puniſhment preparing for thee,
A puniſhment that's worthy thy perfidiouſneſs.
If 'tis ſo terrible to ſee theſe Sights,
So woful but to hear theſe ſounds of Sorrow,
What muſt it be to act the bloody Office?
What muſt it be to one who has a Soul
As ſoft as thine, as melting ev'n as Mercies,

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Ah miſerable me!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: To act it, nay, and act it on a Grecian?
One who himſelf has only tender thoughts,
Or only tender Thoughts at leaſt towards thee.
One who perhaps could die for thee, for whom
Perhaps ev'n thou could'ſt die?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Ah Gods!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: See how her Soul declares its weakneſs,
And now unable to contain its grief,
Pours forth a Deluge of Impetuous Sorrow!
What muſt it be to think the Dreadful time
Of doing this accurſed Deed approaches!
That the next Moment thou muſt ſtain thy Hands,
By going to his Heart a curſed way?
While thy Soul hears th'intolerable Sound
Of his laſt dying Groans, and ſees his Eyes.
His Trembling dying Eyes, that in Deaths cruel'ſt pangs
Look kindly up, as if they bleſt their Murtherer?
Go bring the Eldeſt of the Captives hither,
sp.stage: To ſome of the Guards who go out.
sp.l: Prieſteſs alone, I leave thee with thy Lover,
But know thy Conference with him muſt be ſhort;
And know that yet 'tis in thy power to ſave him.
But let not paſs the irrevocable Moment;
Think that the next comes hurrying on, and then
Unleſs thou firſt perſwad'ſt him to abandon thee,
Thou ſhalt behold him to the Altar drag'd,
Where by thy Hand he dies, and when that's done,
Thou, Thou ſhalt by the ſacred Steel expire,
Thou the devoted Victim of the Goddeſs.
Guards! On your Lives, obſerve them at a diſtance.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Inhuman Queen! Muſt I not only loſe him,
But muſt I urge him to forſake me? No,
Alas thou need'ſt not urge him, ▪that aſſure thy ſelf;
For what would'ſt thou perſwade him to?
To avoid Death, and to embrace a Crown?
A little argument will there prevail,
But the Queen ſays 〈…〉 , is 〈…〉 ?
No, 'tis the Viſion of a 〈…〉 Woman.
But ſay it ſhould be true, forbid it Gods▪
Oh ſhould He love me, 〈…〉 taſte of miſery,

Which ev'n in this 〈…〉
▪
For I could die 〈…〉 he lo •• me,
How can I plead 〈…〉 my ſelf ſucceſsfully?
How can I e'er find 〈…〉 can perſwade him
To make another Happy 〈…〉 thought!
To make another Happy▪ and me Miſerable?
I cannot, I can ſee him 〈…〉 firſt.
Periſh! By whom! Ah w • tch! Inhuman wretch!
And canſt thou then at laſt reſolve to Murder him?
See where He comes, and with a Look ſo ſweet,
As might diſarm ev'n Death, ye Gods, ye Gods,
Who have reſolved that I muſt be a wretch,
Beyond whatever Mortal was before;
Take care that I prevail to my undoing,
And give me ſtrength enough to court Deſpair.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Madam, I come to hear your laſt Commands,
Let them be what they will, yet I with Joy am come.
But why upon this lovely Brow,
So black a clo%d of Sorrow?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Oh could you ſee my Heart▪ and all the Horrour
Which wildly rages there, how would you pity me?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Alas! ev'n now I pity thee!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Do you?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Yes, from my very Soul, you cannot think
How much Compaſſion tears my tortur'd Heart.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Make haſt then, and prevent the curſed Blow,
That I'm compell'd to ſtrike.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Had I a Dagger, I would do it inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: There is an eaſier way at leaſt to you.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Name it.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Grecians abhor.
That Virgins of Affairs like this ſhould ſpeak,
You have beheld 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Wherefore 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Too well 〈…〉
And would not 〈…〉
Which I can never 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Then I am 〈…〉
But why ſhould you 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Reaſon and Juſtice 〈…〉
I love another.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Ha! Then his fatal 〈…〉
What ground the Queen had for her ſtrange ſuſpic • on.
You love another?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: O more than Life, you ſee I love another.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: That let me Hide ev'n from 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Ha! Why ſhould you conceal it from her?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Ask me no more.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: I muſt, and you muſt anſwer.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: She is my Mortal Enemy.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Can any Woman prove a Mortal Enemy▪
To one who loves like you?
Your paſſion known perhaps had made her kind.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: 'Tis to avoid her kindneſs • conceal it.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: T'avoid it?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: More than Ten Thouſand Deaths I dread her kindne ••

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: You love your Enemy, and drea her Kindneſs?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: She is by force, and 〈…〉 Choice my Enemy
She pities me, ev'n from her 〈…〉
Yet my hard Fate compells her to be cruel to me
But ye Gods!
How much I ſuffer from 〈…〉
Than from her Cruelty 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: O Heaven and Earth, I tremble leaſt the Queen
Had but too juſt a ground for her ſuſpicion.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Who can ſee her, he Loves in Grief,
And bear an equal Mind?
How might my Paſſion known, augment her Sorrow?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: But what can force her ſince ſhe is ſo tender,
T'appear your Mortal Enemy?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Why ſhould you ask! Your queſtions but diſturb me!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: I ask to ſave you, and I muſt be anſwer'd;
Speak, what can force her, ſince ſhe is ſo tender,
T'appear your Mortal Enemy?
〈…〉 Thoughts in me,
〈…〉 l Deed.
〈…〉 Fury that thou dream'ſt not of.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Gods! Am I 〈…〉 who loves me!
〈…〉 theſe Convulſions?
〈…〉 Suppoſe that you were forc'd
〈…〉 wou'd it not ſhake you?
〈…〉 Murther,
〈…〉 ſay,
〈…〉 Heart?
〈…〉 you
〈…〉 obey?
sp.p: 〈…〉 like a Fury?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p:
〈◊〉 , how that ſtings ••
▪

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Ha! what, you 〈◊〉 and tremble, and turn pale!
When the bare mention works on you ſo terribly.
Can I endure the thing?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: The Pow'r that you adore, and that commands it,
Will calm, and will ſupport you.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: What if one God commands the dreadful Deed?
Perhaps another mightier Pow'r forbids it;
And if I do it, 〈…〉
Not to be born 〈…〉
Without Deſpair and 〈…〉
Which then ſhall I 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Which of 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Thou ask'ſt 〈…〉
His awful Name's 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: When 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Ev'n now 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Here, 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Here?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Here, look 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Is' he not manifeſt 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Oh aſtoniſhment!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: If thou art blind, 〈…〉
Know, that thou feel'ſt 〈…〉
And own'ſt his dreadful 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Amaſement!
And canſt thou be ſo infinitely 〈…〉

To love this▪ Object of Divine Diſplea ••••
〈…〉
Oh this pathetick Silence how it 〈…〉
How this Diſorder in thy 〈…〉
And quite deſtroys my 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Cou'd you ſee all the 〈…〉
Cou'd you behold my Heart 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: I have been ſhewn 〈…〉
And in that Sight I ſaw a 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Think what's to 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: I do, I do, my Soul's 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Reflect upon my 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Damnation! 〈…〉
And what muſt I endure!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Have Mercy then upon yourſelf and me.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: O for a Dagger!
That plunging it in my Heart's Blood,
I might to both ſhew Mercy.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: That Thought's a Dagger; there's another way.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: No!
My Heart, my Life, my very▪ Soul is yours:
My Honour and my Virtue are the Gods:
They are Depoſitums entruſted with me;
And I'll, untouch'd, with my laſt Breath reſtore them.

〈…〉
Grecian, the Queen has ſent • s to inform thee,
And Death and Vengeance chaſe thee now in view.
Here, you muſt to the Temple guard the Prieſteſs.
And you in Iron Bonds muſt bind the Pris'ner:
Then lead him where the Miniſters expect him,
To bind his Temples, and to veil his Eyes.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Stay but one Moment, when a Wretch requires it,
The only happy Moment I ere knew.

sp.speaker: 1 Scyth.
sp.l: We dare not; for ſeverely we're forbidden.
The Grecians who were ſeen upon the Beach,
With their drawn Weapons 〈…〉
And if thou ſhouldſt 〈…〉
The Queen has ſworn 〈…〉
That we ſhall all of us 〈…〉
D'y' hear? We 〈…〉
The Cornets with their 〈…〉
Bind him, you Slaves 〈…〉
How dare you ſtand 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l:
My Grecians
〈…〉
I'd give the World 〈…〉
But ſince it will 〈…〉
I ask not Liberty, 〈…〉
I ask not ev'n a 〈…〉
Pour down your Plagues on my devoted Head,
Torment me, rack me, • ear me,
Torture me any way, unleſs by torturing he ••
Comfort her poor afflicted Heart, ye Pow'rs!
And grant, that at our next accurſed meeting,
Grant, cruel Gods, that mine be all the Pain.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Break Heart, that we may never meet again.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth ACT.

div.head: ACT. V.

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.p: SAve us ye eternal Pow'rs that ſave the Juſt.

sp.speaker: 2 Priest.
sp.p: Protect us, great Diana!

sp.speaker: 1 Prieſt.
sp.p: What diſmal Night is this?

sp.speaker: 2 Pr.
sp.p: A dreadful Night indeed!

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.p: Sure all the Elements will now be wrack'd,
And 'tis the end of all things.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Are you the Sacred Miniſters of Heav'n,
And yet afraid of Thunder?

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.p: Wh • n Jove's diſturb'd, what Mortal dares be calm?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I who am conſcious of committing nothing,
That may provoke his Anger.
Are all things ready?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: They are, ev'n now th'adorn the fatal Image.

〈…〉
Grecians are 〈…〉 And is it poſſible?
〈…〉 could they force in ſpight of your reſiſtance,
〈…〉 up the M • un ••• n's Steep aſcent?
〈…〉 You have heard how firſt by ſlow Degrees they aſcended,
While as they mounted d • sky Clouds aroſe
And Heaven appear'd to ſ • o • l upon th' Attempt,
And lowring blacken'd all their March, while ours
Upon the Margin of the horrid Summet,
With threatning Dares impatiently expected them.
But when within our Javelins reach they arriv'd
Upon the ſudden Jove declar'd aloud for them.
The dreadful Thunder from behind them roar'd,
While at our Scythians Eyes the blaſting Lightning flew,
The Grecians with a ſhout that breath'd Defiance,
Receiv'd th' Auſpicious Signal; and the Thunder
Seem'd as an Inſtrument of War t'excite them.
Hear ye Barbarians! H • ar great Jove they cryed,
Threatning Deſtruction to your curſed Race.
And as the Rocks Reſtor'd the Dreadful cry
Murmuring they claſh'd a formidable Din
Upon their flaming Shields, then ſhook their Horrid Spears,
Their Spears that briſtled with th'amazing Beams
Of the Retorted Lightning; Hideous they aſcended,
As flaming Furies mounting from the Abyſs,
While all our Scythians look'd like pale Offenders,
When they behold Hell's Ghaſtly 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p:
Infamous Slave •
〈…〉

sp.speaker: Scyth.
sp.l:
This fron •
〈…〉
Where I, great Queen, by 〈…〉
Prepar'd the 〈…〉
When lo the 〈…〉
The Mournful 〈…〉
When in 〈…〉
I hurrying drag 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: And 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Scyth.
sp.l: Not I 〈…〉
As we were 〈…〉
The Grecians that 〈…〉
Had driv'n our 〈…〉
And quite o'ercome 〈…〉
Swift as the Lightning 〈…〉
And in a Moment, 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: And thou art alive to tell this▪

sp.speaker: Scyth.
sp.l: My Life was of Importance to your Service▪
And therefore I preſerv'd it.
A panick Fear had now diſpers'd our Scythians▪
Some fell, ſome ſled, but all remain'd Diſorder'd.
Iby this Voice alone retriev'd the Fainting,
Confirm'd the Doubtful, and recall'd the Flying:
Ralli • d by me, they ſtill maintain'd their ground,
When I withdrew to inform▪ you of your Danger,
And know your further pleaſur •

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: O Death to all my Hopes! [Aſide] Return I charge 〈…〉
And tell th • ſe Scandals to the Scythian Race,
That they had better never have been born,
Than • 'er behold my Ev •• without the Priſoner?
Tell them, they can but dieby Grecian Hands;
And if they die by them, they die with Honour,
And they who die with Honour, die with Pleaſure.
But ſhould they owe their Deaths to my Revenge,
O • Thou, O Heaven! that ſhouts the ſhout of Triumph,
• ead in my Eyes the Reſt, and fly to inform them.

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.p: The Gods apparently reject this Sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: How durſt thou think ſo?

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.l: The prodigies ſo lately ſeen confirm it.
Scarce had the Night upon her Carr aſcending,
Thrown her black Influence round the Mournful Hemiſphere,
When a Mad Whirlwinds Subterranean blaſt,
Made the Dome tremble from its deep Foundation.
And ſhook the dreadful glories of its Spires.
Yet hide themſelves from 〈…〉 they have given
A Spirit, worthy of the 〈…〉 ?

Ha! Art thou then return'd▪ What do 〈…〉
Grecians?

sp.speaker: Scyth.
sp.p: The Grecians make a ſurely ſlow Retreat.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: And where's the Victim?

sp.speaker: Scyth.
sp.p: Look where the Scythians guard him towards the Altar.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: You are juſt ye pow'rs in all your ways!
Now let the Rites begin.

div.stage:
The flat Scene draws and diſcovers the Altar, Iphigenia on the one ſide, and Euphroſine on the other in Mourning postures. The Victim veild is introduced by flat Trumpets, a Train of Prieſts and
Prieſteſſes and Guards. The Victim is led 〈…〉 ; after that a dreadful Symphony, and then the following Ode.
Ode for the Sacrifice. Three Prieſts, Chorus of Prieſts and Prieſteſſes.

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.p:
HAil great Diana,
• ear and ſ •• ,

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: We Sacrifice thee.

sp.speaker: 2 Pr.
sp.l: Hail Moon that with thy ſilver Light,
Govern'ſt the Empire of the Night,
Look down and ſee,

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: We Sacrifice to thee.

sp.speaker: 3 Pr.
sp.l: And thou the Dreadfull'ſt of the three,
Hail Infernal Hecate!
Aſcend and ſee!

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: We Sacrifice to thee.

div.head: II.
div.l: Thee, Great Diana, thee,
Goddeſs renown'd for Chaſtity,
Thee firſt of all we Invoke,
To ſee us ſtrike the fatal ſtroke.
On him who with a Heart prophane,
Thy very Altars ſought to ſtain.
Thy preſence open'd the dark Womb
And gave him Entrance to the Light;
Thy preſence too muſt open the ſad Tomb,
And ſend him to Eternal Night.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: Thee Goddeſs, thee, we all invoke
To ſee us ſtrike the fatal ſtroke.

sp.speaker: 2 Pr.
sp.l: Thou Mo • n that with thy Silver Light,
Govern'ſt the Empire of the Night;
Thee, Goddeſs, thee, we next Invoke,
To ſee the fatal ſtroke.
As Horrour thou art pleas'd to ſee,
Horror loves to g ••• on thee.
Each Fiend, and ev'ry ghaſtly Spright
That ſo abhors thy Brother's Ray,
Yet oft forſakes eternal Night
To revel in thy paler Day.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: Thee, Goddeſs, Thee we next invoke,
Look down and ſee the fatal Stroke.

sp.speaker: 2 Chor.
sp.l: She ſees, ſhe ſees, a gloomy Red
H •• half her glowing Face o'erſpread.
But, • h behold, o'er half her Light,
I • muſt be ſome Theſſalian Charm,
〈◊〉 , 〈◊〉 your Trumpets, give the alarm;

Let •••
〈…〉 the Sky,
〈…〉 your Drums,

A ••
••• the Victim die.

sp.speaker: 2 Pr.
sp.l: But hold, till laſtly thee,
Queen of Furies we invoke,
Aſcend and ſee the fatal Stroke.
Aſcend from everlaſting Night,
Blaſting Nature with the ſight;

div.head: VI.
div.l: She comes, ſhe cleaves the trembling Ground,
And ſpreading horrour all around,
D ••• ly dies the miſty Air,
Her dark and gri •• ly Features fright,
The coal black Steeds that drag the Night,
And Nature's Ce • ti • els they ſc • re,
Heark how with dreary Shriek the Owl,
And▪ frighted W • lv • s with dreadful Howl,
Her dire approach declare.

sp.speaker: Chorus:
sp.l: She's here, her Guard of Furies ſe • ,
And Furies now as great are we,
Her Spirit rages in our Souls,
And in our frantick Eyes it rowls.
To the diſmal Deed ſhe's come to excite us,
And nothing but Blood can delight us;
Give us Blood, give us Blood,
Give us a Flood,
Let it flow, let it flow,
Strike, ſtrike the fatal Blow.

div.stage: A ſhout juſt as the Ode ends.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Oh inſolence, audacious, inſupportable!
Look out and ſee who 'tis that dares diſturb
The Execution of this dreadful Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: Great Queen, provide betimes for your ſecurity,
The Greeks returning, bear down all before them,
And the next moment will inveſt the Temple.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Are all the Gates madefaſt?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.p: They'r all with Bars of ſolid Braſs ſecur'd.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Then I'll prevent them, Prieſteſs do thy Duty.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: Goddeſs, look down, thy Prieſteſs is thy Victim.

div.stage:
Offers to ſtab herſelf, the Victim throws off his Veil, and 〈…〉 the Knife from her, diſcovering himſelf to be Pilades;
〈…〉 ſame time ſpeaking as follows.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Oh hold, 'tis Sacrilege to ſtrike that ſtroke,
Thy Beauties are the Darling care of Heav'n;
Look up, and ſee the Wonder it has wrought
On purpoſe to preſerve them.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: May I believe my Eyes! Amazing ſight!

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.p: Miraculous Events!

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Thou thought'ſt to die for the dear Man thou lov'ſt,
And I, alas, am come to die for him.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: O all ye Pow'rs whoſe Wiſdom rules the Univerſe,
Let me adore the Wonders of your Providence!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Revenge thy, injur'd Handmaid, great Diana!
Revenge thy injur'd ſelf, we're both betray'd,
By my own faithleſs Subjects we're betray'd.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: No, cruel Queen, thou ſee'ſt I am come to die,
And ſatisfie you both.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Where is thy Friend?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: Where! at the Head of his Victorious Grecians.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Oh, curſed Fate!
What brought thee here, to ſuffer in his ſtead?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Agreement with your Scythians, and deſire
To ſave the only Man of all the World,
That's fit to be a Friend, by gaining time
Enough for his Embarkment.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: What haſt thou ſaid? Agreement with my Scythians?
Oh the vile Traitors! Why ſhould they agree to it?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: To ſave themſelves.
After our Greeks had forced my God-like Friend from them,
They who ſoon found their Victim irretrievable,
And knew what torments they muſt undergo,
Unleſs they could make you think they had retriev'd him,
They who with Wonder had beheld the Pow'r
Of 〈…〉 Friendſhip in my Friend and me,
To my Apartment c • me half dead with fear,
VVhere they inform'd me of our Gr •••••• Valour,
Your Threats, their baſeneſs, and my Friend's eſcape,
I 〈…〉 gain time for hi • Embarkment,
〈…〉 and die for him.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: 〈…〉 the Altar thus unbound?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: 〈…〉 I agreed with them.
Death 〈…〉 embrac'd,
But the 〈…〉 of a Slave,
My free •••• ſoul diſdain'd▪
〈…〉 W •• ever any thing thing ſo great?
〈…〉 And yet ſo tender and ſo true?
〈…〉 me Grecian, but ſo nobly,
〈…〉 beauteous as thy Fraud,
〈…〉 that thou muſt die,
〈…〉 a God like Action!

〈…〉
• he! Muſt he die for it?
〈…〉 it all ye Pow'rs!
〈…〉 ſelves inſpir'd this wondrous Virtue,
〈…〉 leaſt, he ne'er ſhall die.

〈…〉 . But die th ••
•• ſt;
〈…〉 Rites, and great Revenge require it.
〈…〉 thy Office.
〈…〉 O • never, never!
〈…〉 . Ah, miſerable Creature! think with trembling,
What Vengeance thou art drawing on thy Head.
••• the time preſſes, I ſhall be prevented,
• ake thou the ſacred Steel, and ſtrike the Blow.

sp.speaker: Scyth.
sp.p: Make way for the Elder of the Captives there, Make way.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: For the Elder of the Captives!

div.stage: As the other Prieſteſs is going to ſtrik • , Oreſtes enters, runs between the Dagger and Pilades, and embraces him.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: He lives, he lives, I have him in my Arms,
This turn, ye Pow'rs, has made amends for all.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l:
Confuſion! I am loſt, the Greek •
are here,
Strike thro' them both.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Ah, cruel fight! Ah, Gods! I cannot bear it.
Thus, let me intercept the barbarous Blow.

div.stage: A • the other Prieſteſs goes to ſtrike, Iphigenia interpoſes.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: O Death and Vengeance! Her, her Heart transfix.

sp.speaker: Prieſt.
sp.p: Who's the chief Prieſteſs?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Hers, li • t thy ex ••• ting Arm, haſte, ſtrike,
I'm loſt, undone, on every ſide betray'd,
And the next moment we ſhall be prevented.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: O hurt not her, by Heav'n and Earth I adjure you▪
• o • I am come alone, and come to die.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: What ſay'ſt thou? 'Tis impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: 'Tis certain.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Wert thou not Reſcued by thy Friends?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: I was▪

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Haſt thou been retaken then by our S • ythians?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Your Scythians are diſpers'd, and we are Victors.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Where are thy Grecians then?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Upon the horrid ſommet of the Cliff,
By my Command, obſequiouſly they wait.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: How got you entrance?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: At the Iron Wicket of the Poſtern, where
Arm'd with a hundred Javelins, Death ſtands Centry,
And none can there unlicens'd paſs and live.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: What brought thee to this fatal place alone?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: I come to die.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Thou com'ſt to die! the Conquerour comes to die!

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Af • er our Greeks had forced me from your Scythians,
As ſoon as the Retreat we ſlowly made,
Had giv'n me time for thought;
My Joy ſoon vaniſh'd all, for ſoon I found
That I had left all that I held moſt precious,
All that was dear to my afflicted Soul,
Ev'n in the Jaws of Fate,
Strait I prevail'd upon my valiant Friends
T'attempt a ſecond Reſcue.
Then to my Friend's Apartment we all flew,
To force his Guards, the Guards indeed we forc'd,
But him we found not, there I grew inform'd
Of his deplorable, tho' God▪like purpoſe;
That his inimitable Love for me
Made him to a bloody doom devoted ſtand,
At theſe inhumane Altars.
Swift as a Storm we hurried to the Temple,
But when I found the Maſſy Gates all barr'd,
The dreadful Rites begun, and my poor Friend
At the Altar, and about to breath his laſt,
To breath his laſt for me;
Witneſs ye Pow'rs, that thought I could not bear,
With rigorous Commands I enjoyn'd my Friends
To leave me to the adverſe Gods and Fate.
For Gods and Fate cry'd out that I muſt bleed,
Or elſe ſurviving ev'ry minute die▪
And here alone th • Conquerou • 's come to die.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Unheard of Friendſhip!

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.p: Un •• ampl • d Faith!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: O Conſt • ncy Di • i •• !

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l:
Was 〈◊〉
••• n ſo great a ſight
Of glorio • s W • e before!

sp.speaker: Euph. to Iph.
sp.l: Courage, my Princeſs, for the Gods declare for us,
They are here among us▪ they are manifeſt;
For theſe are plainly more than Human Actions▪

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I am o'recome, I yield y' Almighty Powers,
To hurt ſuch Vi •• ue were to touch your ſelves,
Such Virtue is Divi • ity.
Here, ſet them free immediately.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: The Grecians.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Both?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Both.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Then, wh • re's the Victim for our Solemn Rites?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: The Goddeſs has herſelf declar'd her Victim.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Enquire no more, but ſet thy Priſoners free.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: They are free.

sp.speaker: Queen▪ to Or.
sp.l: Gr • cian I need not be aſham'd to own
That I am charm'd by thy exalted Virtue.
The Immortal Powers themſelves are fond of leſs.
Twice in one night has it prevail'd upon me
To give thee Life, to give thee Liberty;
But ſince thou ſhew'ſt thou valueſt not thy own,
I here beſtow thy Friends upon thee too.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: From my ſoul▪ I thank you.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l:
But Cuſtom, which▪
〈◊〉
Scy •• i •••
Law▪ requires▪

That they whom my Pr • rogative▪
••• s free,

Muſt become Scythians▪ by Eſpouſing Scythian •
▪
Or—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: But Liberty in that too will be neceſſary.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: As free as is the Wind ſhall be thy choice:
Thou ſhalt be for • 'd in nothing, yet permit me▪
To give thy Wife a Dowry worthy thee.
Thy Souls ſurpaſſing greatneſs I admire!
Which Heaven that form'd it ſure deſign'd for Empire;
Accept of mine, thy wiſer nobler Sway
Will poliſh theſe Barbarians into Men.
Thine are the vaſt extended Plains of Tauris.
My ſelf, my Subjects, Men and Women, all
Shall govern'd be by thy unbounded Sway;
The Soveraign Partner of thy Royal Bed
Among a thouſand Scythian Beauties chooſe,
And make her happy who's moſt worthy thee.
Then I am loſt again.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: Art thou not mov'd?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Amaz'd, confounded, Gods! Are theſe the words
Of a Barbarian, of a Savage Scythian?
But, be ſhe what ſhe will
Such generous Paſſion I ne'r knew till now,
No, not in Greece, but oh its Artful modeſty!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: What, no reply?
My Preſent ſure deſerves at leaſt your Thanks.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Oh! It deſerves much more than I can pay!
Oh! It deſerves my Heart, my very Soul:
And now, ev'n now I ought to be beheld
Paying my Adorations at your Feet;
And off'ring all my ſelf with fervent Vows.
But oh! have pitty on ſo loſt a Creature,
Who has no Heart, no Soul, no Vows to pay,
Who has given all theſe, who has given himſelf away
A Voluntary Slave, one ſo accurſt,
That though he mortally deteſts Ingratitude,
Yet wants the power, nay wants the very will
To pay th' Immenſe acknowledgment he owes.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Suppoſe ſome God ſhould free you from this Paſſion?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: I wiſh not to be free:

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Yet put the Caſe you were this moment free,
Might I expect to find you grateful then?
For Grecian, I am loth to think you hate me.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Hate you! O Heaven! of all your lovely Sex
You I eſteem, and you I moſt admire,
Should I ſay more, I baſely ſhould deceive you.
To wrong you in that Nature, that indeed
Would be the height of black ingratitude.
For all my ſofter thoughts another claims;
Who, though the tendereſt of her gentle Sex,
Yet has a Tyrants force upon my Soul.
But were I not prevented by that Paſſion,
Now Proſtrate at your Feet you ſhould behold me,
Prouder to obey your abſolute Commands
Than to Controul th' extended Plains of Tauris.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: May I believe thee?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Yes, could I haue reſolv'd to ſay what's falſe,
You had heard a falſhood that would more have pleas'd you.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: But ſwear.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Propoſe the Oath.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Swear by the dreadful Altar you have eſcap'd.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: By this Tremendous Altar then I ſwear.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: This Altar then ſhall free that from a Paſſion
That's ſo unworthy thee, 〈◊〉 like the Prieſteſs,
For her the Goddeſs 〈◊◊〉 her Victim.
Here, take 〈◊〉 , bind 〈◊〉 drag her to the Altar,

And in he •
〈◊〉 ſome plunge the Sacred Steel.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: O Heaven! The Prieſteſs!

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Impious Propoſal!

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: Think not that we will e're endure that ſight.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Think not that you'll endure it! Think where you are.
You both are in my power.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: They who dare die are always in their own.
Our Breaſts ſhall intercept th' accurſed blow.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Guards, 'tis your Duty to take care of that.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: No barbarous power can force us to ſurvive her.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Die then, and prove the Plagues which for the Perjur'd
The direful Goddeſſes prepare below,
As ſoon as ſhe expires, thou to be mine
Haſt by th' inviolable Altar ſworn.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: In what a Maſe, O Fate, am I entangled!
But think, reflect, by all the Gods I adjure you.
And Oh regard that lovely dying Face,
Meek and reſign'd in theſe extreameſt Sufferings.
Oh look and ſtop th' Abominable Blow!
Mercy, ſweet Mercy will it ſelf
Be murder'd by that Blow.
Look, caſt your Eyes around, behold a ſight
Enough to diſſolve Flint, ſee theſe Barbarians
Whoſe Eyes have been inur'd to ghaſtly Murder,
Whoſe Cr •• ſon Arms are dy'd with horrid Grain,
Ev'n they Diſſolve, they me •• their Eyes ſhed Tears,
Thoſe Cruel Eyes that • ever 〈◊〉 before.
Look how they're ſeiz'd with hidden Horror all!
But above all look up, be hold your Goddeſs!
Think that you ſee her 〈◊〉 wrathful Frown
Denouncing Plagues on your Devoted Heads!
Think that already her avenging Arms
Are lifted, and prepare the dreadful Judgments
That muſt be pour'd on this accurſed Race,
Revenging with its utter extirpation,
Her Prieſteſs Murder'd, and here Shrine prophan'd.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Seythians, 'tis true.
Theſe Judgments we muſt fearfully expect
If we lay impious Hands upon the Prieſteſs.

sp.speaker: All Scyth.
sp.p: Unbind the Prieſteſs, ſet her free immediately.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Hear me firſt, Scythians, and you Grecians hear!
Scythians, what ſlaviſh Doubt has ſeiz'd your Souls?
What • ear you? To provoke the dreadful Goddeſs!
This is her Victim; ſhe her ſelf has claim'd her;
Nay, and with ſo much vehemence has claim'd her,
She left th' Immortal Manſions of bleſt Beings
On purpoſe to demand her, and too long
This Prieſteſs has already liv'd Devoted to her.
I till this hour, forgive it awful Goddeſs,
I by a Tender weakneſs mov'd, preſerv'd her;
And Heaven beſt knows how I have been rewarded.
Now for you, Grecians, you too ſhall be ſatisfi'd.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: No, never, if ſhe dies.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Yes, though ſhe dies, for when you know this Prieſteſs
You will your ſelves demand and urge her Fate.
At leaſt if you're the Sons of thoſe brave Grecians
Who carried their Heroick Arms to Aſia,
And with a thouſand Sail Beleaguer'd Troy.
With one accord your Fathers urg'd her Fate,
Nay her own Father to the Altar doom'd her,
Becauſe the ſevere Goddeſs had exacted her.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: May I believe my Senſe? Am I awake!

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: O all y' Immortal Powers! How am I tortur'd
By the fierce pangs of wondrous Expectation!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: But Death by her Mothers Artifice ſhe eſcap'd,
While a young Lesbian Slave in Shape and Size
And Age reſembling hers, in a long Veil
Was at the Altal offer'd in hear ſtead.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Support me! Gods! Support me!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Why doſt thou thus exclaiming interrupt me?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Oh! I have moſt amazing things to tell you!
But firſt Important Queſtions I muſt ask.
I have Important things t' enquire of her.
And Queen, aſſure thy ſelf on what I ſay
Thy Peace, thy laſting Happineſs depends.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Speak, but be ſhort then, what are the Gods doing!

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Say then, poor, loſt, abandon'd Virgin, ſay,
Didſt thou from bleeding at a Grecian Altar
By thy fond Mothers Artifice eſcape!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: I did, and thank the Gods a thouſand times for it;
By that eſcape I have liv'd to dye for thee.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Talk not of Death, alas, but anſwer me,
O thou art ſure the▪ Darling Care of Providence,
And it has wrought prodigious things to ſave thee!
How com •• it that thy ſtrange Eſcape▪ in Greece
Was never hea • d or talk'd of •

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Of 〈…〉 wretched Parents
Were 〈…〉 it, 〈…〉 night inform'd me
They • adly 〈…〉 by a 〈…〉 .

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: O Miracle of 〈…〉 O Tranſport▪

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l:
My Siſters both werein 〈…〉
• nfancy,
My Brother ſcarce had ſeen the 〈…〉 .

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: By Heav'n and •• rth it can be no •• but 〈…〉 ,
See Helens Form upon that lovely Front!
Anſwer but one thing more, ſay from what Altar
Didſt thou eſcape, and by what Artifice?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Alas 'tis a long Story,
And my weak Spirits, by my Grief oppreſt,
Will let me ſay no more.
But in my Cabinet it large 'tis written,
Yet grant me this, my firſt and laſt Requeſt,
To Greece tranſport the Writing.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Talk not of Writing • , Writing • may be loſt;
But tell me in a word what I muſt ſay,
What and to whom?

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Inform my Friends and Kindred then • t Argos,

That the forlorn abandon'd
〈…〉
—

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: O ſupreme Jov • , whoſe P ••• idence has wrought this!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: What makes you lif • your 〈…〉 to Heaven,
And ſtarting thus exclaim?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Was ever Viſion of the Night ſo ſtrange,
So wonderful as this! Say on, ſay on.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Tell them at Argos, that •• or Iphigenia,

Whom fondly they believ'd at
〈…〉
ſacri •• c'd,
Eſcap'd the Altar there▪ but that the Goddeſs
Upon the Shore of Ta • ris found her Victim.
And with, O wiſh my Brother, my Oreſtes,
A much more gentle Fate!

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: Thus, thus, thy Brother, thy Oreſtes thanks thee.

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.p: My Brother! Oh!

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.p: My deareſt Siſter!

sp.speaker: Iph.
sp.l: Can it be true!
Or does my Senſe, grown wild with Grief, delude me?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Her Brother! is it poſſible! her Brother!

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.p:
Her Brother! and the powerful King of Argo •
▪

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Is't poſſible! O the tranſporting Joy!
Impetuous Flood of unexpected Rapture!
Whether I live or no I cannot tell.
Haſte, Scythians, haſte, upon your knees unbind her.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Hold off your barbarous hands, preſumptuous Slaves,
And let a Prince be honour'd with that Task.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: O Queen! O Friend! O Siſter!
Was ever Night like this!

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Thus to theſe lovely Limbs I Liberty reſtore.
O woul • but the good Gods and ſhe conſent
That I for ever might remain a Captive.

sp.speaker: Qu. to Iph.
sp.l: Canſt thou forgive me all this cruel Uſage,
Of which Love only could have made me guilty?
Canſt thou, thou tend'reſt of all Humankind?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Can you ſo much as ask it? all my Soul
Is to tranſporting Tenderneſs reſign'd.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Thou art all Goodneſs; in this ſtrict Embrace
Let all Unkindneſs be forgot for ever.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Now, how ſhall we pay equal Thanks to Heav'n,
For this ſo great, ſo wonderful Deliverance?
Chiefly with flaming Zeal our Thanks to thee,
To thee our Thanks we pay, Divine Apollo!
And thy unerring Oracle adore.
Next, let me pay my Debt to thee, my Pilades,
And with the beſt of Siſters let me bleſs
The kindeſt, trueſt and the beſt of Friends.
She cannot now be mine, and ne'er ſhall be anothers,
Take her my Friend, thou art my very ſelf,
The other, dearer Half of thy Oreſtes.
Take her, and with her take ten thouſand Joys,
All the high Raptures thy fierce Paſſion promiſes▪
Thou anſwer'ſt not.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Oh, I want Breath to ſpeak, I die with Ecſtaſie!
And my tumultuous Thoughts above all Words are rais'd▪
Here let me with dumb Eloquence experſs 'em,
Here pour out the abundance of my Soul.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: And next to you, great Queen, I pay my Acknowledgments,
And now with Joy accept this Realm of Tauris,
That at your Feet you may behold a Slave
With two Imperial Sceptres.
And now prepare to leave this barbarous Clime,
Here but by Deputy henceforward reign,
The Gods ſuch Worth deſign'd to govern Greece,
To ſhine the Glory of the braveſt Nation,
And give example to a Race of Heroines,
Who have Force to follow ſo ſublime a Pattern.
Your Goddeſs is the Partner of your Voyage.
Whoſe Image great Apollo's Deplhick Oracle▪
Has with reiterated Voice demanded.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: The Prodigies of this •• upendous Night,
And Viſion of the laſt confirm that Oracle.
With me the Goddeſs ſhall to Greece remove,
And theſe inhumane Rites ſhall ceaſe for ever.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: The Gods are good, and Lovers of Mankind,
And that Religion that allows of Cruelty
Is not divine, but impious and abominable.
Laſtly our Thanks once more we pay to thee,
Son of immortal Jove, divine Apollo,
Who haſt made good thy bounteous Oracles.
We are preſerv'd, and mighty Love preſerves us.
Now, from this wond'rous Night let Mortals learn,
When in obedience to the Gods they tread
The doubtful Paths of Deſtiny, to affront
The dreadfulleſt Dangers with a dauntleſs Spirit.
Let 'em not ev'n in worſt Extreams deſpair;
For while they keep to Virtue's narrow Paths,
With Guards invincible they march ſurrounded.
The Gods who ſurely guide them on the way,
From them no more than from themſelves can ſtray,
For Virtue's of Divinity a Ray.

div.head: EP • LOGUE, by Coll. Codrington.
div.l: OUR Bard ſhall end to night, as He began,
Prologue, Play, Epilogue ſhall ſpeak the Man,
Shew a more Tragick Poet if you can.
With Pride he owns that he would gain your Hearts,
But he will uſe no little Whoriſh Arts.
With Pride he owns, that 'tis his glorious Aim
To court and to poſſeſs the Tragick Dame.
How can he court, or how can be poſſeſs,
Who ſhames the Goddeſs by a forein Dreſs?
That decks her like a trivial merry Muſe,
Or a rank Strumpet, ſtrolling from the Stews.
Yet thus diſguis'd ſhe oft has here been ſhown,
To all her genuine Votaries unknown,
Yet still you thought the motly Garb her own.
Oft have you ſeen her with the Comick Muſe,
Walk hand in hand, Grimace and Poſture uſe,
Debaſe her Majesty and Terror loſe.
What needs ſuch Art your kind Applauſe to win
What need ſuch Farce to drive away your Spleen,
Who thus are pleas'd have Farce enough within.
Our Bard reſolves to steer a diff'rent Courſe,
And travel upwards to the Grecian Source.
Where he at firſt ſaw the chast, awful Maid,
And with obſerving Eyes her Charms ſurvey'd.
Thoſe Charms he would with a bold hand expreſs,
Nor make 'em • ainter by an Engliſh Dreſs.
To pleaſe the Great, the Gen'rous, and the Fair,
Shall • ver be his Pride, and be his Care.
Next he would ſtand the knowing Criticks Teſt,
To Fortune unconcern'd he leaves the reſt.
For well he knows the Ignorant and the Baſe
Scatter in waſte their Cenſure and their Praiſe.
